title: Create /work command to orchestrate prep→cook→serve→tidy sequence
description:
Create a /work command for line-cook that orchestrates the full workflow loop:

1. /prep - sync state, load context, show available work
2. /cook - select and execute a task with guardrails
3. /serve - review completed work
4. /tidy - commit and push

The command should run each step in sequence, passing context between them. Provides a single entry point for a complete work cycle.

title: Create plugin from repo and install locally
Review meta-opencode for best practices on skills, commands, and plugins
description:
Review ~/code/meta-opencode to understand best practices for creating:
- Skills
- Commands  
- Plugins

Use findings to inform the opencode port of line-cook commands.

comments.author: Sam Biggins
comments.text:
Key findings from meta-opencode review:

## Commands (OpenCode)
- Location: .opencode/command/<name>.md or plugin/commands/<name>.md
- Frontmatter: description, agent, model, subtask
- Template variables: $ARGUMENTS, $1, $2, etc.
- Shell output: !`command`
- File references: @path/to/file

## Skills (OpenCode)
- Location: .opencode/skills/<name>/SKILL.md
- Frontmatter: name (kebab-case), description, license, compatibility, metadata
- Progressive disclosure: lazy-loadable subdirectories
- Must be SKILL.md (uppercase)

## Plugin Manifest (OpenCode)
- Uses package.json with 'opencode' section
- Lists skills[] and commands[] arrays
- Can be distributed as npm package (.tgz)

## Key Differences from Claude Code
- Commands in .opencode/command/ vs .claude/commands/
- Skills in .opencode/skills/ vs .claude/skills/
- Plugin manifest in package.json vs plugin.json
- Template syntax: $1/$2 vs $ARGUMENTS only in Claude

title: Create opencode version of line-cook commands and plugin
description:
Port all line-cook commands to opencode format:
- /prep
- /cook  
- /serve
- /tidy
- /work

Also create an opencode plugin manifest equivalent to .claude-plugin/plugin.json.

Depends on reviewing meta-opencode best practices first.

title: tidy should not ask user questions - file issues as beads instead
description: The /tidy command currently asks the user questions about issues, documentation updates, etc. It should instead operate non-interactively: any errors, warnings, concerns, or clarifications discovered should be filed as beads (P3/P4) for later processing. This keeps the workflow moving and avoids blocking on user input.

comments.author: Sam Biggins
comments.text:
Review Results:
Verdict: approved
Summary: Makes /tidy command non-interactive by filing concerns as beads instead of prompting user
Issues: 0 (0 auto-fixed, 0 beads created)
Positive: Clean implementation following the 'file, don't block' pattern
